title: How to Make Chocolate Syrup Brownies

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350ºF (177ºC) and grease a jelly roll or brownie pan.
steps.description: You can use butter or cooking spray to grease the pan. You can use a 9 by 13-inch (22.86 by 33.02 centimeters) pan, or a 10 by 15-inch (25.4 by 38.1 centimeters) pan.

steps.headline: Beat the butter and sugar until light and creamy.
steps.description: You can do this using a handheld mixer, an electric stand mixer, or even a food processor. You can also do it by hand, but it will take longer. Keep mixing the butter and sugar until they are evenly combined. To make the process go by faster, cut the butter into smaller cubes first.

steps.headline: Slowly beat the eggs in, one at a time.
steps.description: If you are using an electric mixer, set the speed to low, and add the eggs in while it is beating. Keep beating until the eggs are evenly mixed in.

steps.headline: Stir in the vanilla extract and chocolate syrup, then set it aside.
steps.description: Pour in the vanilla extract and chocolate syrup, then stir it until everything is evenly combined. There should be no streaks or swirls of chocolate syrup.

steps.headline: Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt in a separate bowl.
steps.description: In a large mixing bowl, add the flour, baking powder, and salt. Stir them briskly together using a whisk or spoon.

steps.headline: Add the flour mixture into the syrup mixture and stir well.
steps.description: Keep stirring until everything is evenly blended together. Make sure that there are no lumps or clumps of flour. If there are any, use a whisk to break them up.

steps.headline: Consider adding 1 cup (110 grams) of chopped walnuts or chocolate chips.
steps.description: This is not completely necessary, but it will add some extra flavor and texture to your brownies. For the chocolate chips, consider dark chocolate chips or semi-sweet chocolate chips.

steps.headline: Pour the batter into the pan.
steps.description: Use a spatula to help spread the batter evenly across the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Bake the brownies for 22 to 40 minutes, depending on the size of the pan you are using.
steps.description: The brownies are ready when the center springs back if you press down on it lightly. Another way to check for doneness is by sticking a toothpick in the center. If it comes out clean, the brownies are ready. If you are using a 9 by 13-inch (22.86 by 33.02 centimeters) pan, bake the brownies for 35 to 40 minutes. If you are using a 10 by 15-inch (25.4 by 38.1 centimeters) pan, bake the brownies for 22 to 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Take the brownies out of the oven and let them cool, about 5 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: While the brownies are cooling, you can start preparing the frosting.

steps.headline: Heat the butter, milk, and sugar in a saucepan until the butter melts and the sugar dissolves.
steps.description: Pour the milk into a medium-sized saucepan, then add the sugar. Cut the butter into smaller cubes, and toss it in. Cook the mixture over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the butter melts and the sugar dissolves.

steps.headline: Bring the butter mixture to a boil and cook it for 30 seconds.
steps.description: Stir the mixture often to prevent it from scorching or forming a skin on top.

steps.headline: Remove the saucepan from the stove and stir in the chocolate chips.
steps.description: Keep stirring until the chocolate chips melt. If the chocolate chips are not melting at all, place the saucepan back onto the stove, and turn the heat on to low. Stir the mixture until the chocolate chips melt, then remove the saucepan from heat.

steps.headline: Let the mixture cool a little before pouring it over the brownies.
steps.description: The mixture will thicken a little as it cools. This will not only make it easier to spread, but also prevent it from soaking into the brownies.

steps.headline: Consider sprinkling chopped walnuts over the fudge topping.
steps.description: This is not completely necessary, but it will give your brownies some extra flavor and texture. How much chopped walnuts you add is entirely up to you, but you still want to be able to see the fudge frosting.

steps.headline: Allow the frosting to set before cutting and serving the brownies.
steps.description: The frosting will eventually harden up like fudge. Once the frosting is set and the brownies are completely coo, you can cut them into squares and serve them.

tyn: Jelly roll pan or brownie pan
text: Making the Brownies Preheat your oven to 350ºF (177ºC) and grease a jelly roll or brownie pan. You can use butter or cooking spray to grease the pan. You can use a 9 by 13-inch (22.86 by 33.02 centimeters) pan, or a 10 by 15-inch (25.4 by 38.1 centimeters) pan. Beat the butter and sugar until light and creamy. You can do this using a handheld mixer, an electric stand mixer, or even a food processor. You can also do it by hand, but it will take longer. Keep mixing the butter and sugar until they are evenly combined. To make the process go by faster, cut the butter into smaller cubes first. Slowly beat the eggs in, one at a time. If you are using an electric mixer, set the speed to low, and add the eggs in while it is beating. Keep beating until the eggs are evenly mixed in. Stir in the vanilla extract and chocolate syrup, then set it aside. Pour in the vanilla extract and chocolate syrup, then stir it until everything is evenly combined. There should be no streaks or swirls of chocolate syrup. Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt in a separate bowl. In a large mixing bowl, add the flour, baking powder, and salt. Stir them briskly together using a whisk or spoon. Add the flour mixture into the syrup mixture and stir well. Keep stirring until everything is evenly blended together. Make sure that there are no lumps or clumps of flour. If there are any, use a whisk to break them up. Consider adding 1 cup (110 grams) of chopped walnuts or chocolate chips. This is not completely necessary, but it will add some extra flavor and texture to your brownies. For the chocolate chips, consider dark chocolate chips or semi-sweet chocolate chips. Pour the batter into the pan. Use a spatula to help spread the batter evenly across the bottom of the pan. Bake the brownies for 22 to 40 minutes, depending on the size of the pan you are using. The brownies are ready when the center springs back if you press down on it lightly. Another way to check for doneness is by sticking a toothpick in the center. If it comes out clean, the brownies are ready. If you are using a 9 by 13-inch (22.86 by 33.02 centimeters) pan, bake the brownies for 35 to 40 minutes. If you are using a 10 by 15-inch (25.4 by 38.1 centimeters) pan, bake the brownies for 22 to 30 minutes. Take the brownies out of the oven and let them cool, about 5 to 10 minutes. While the brownies are cooling, you can start preparing the frosting. Making the Frosting Heat the butter, milk, and sugar in a saucepan until the butter melts and the sugar dissolves. Pour the milk into a medium-sized saucepan, then add the sugar. Cut the butter into smaller cubes, and toss it in. Cook the mixture over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the butter melts and the sugar dissolves. Bring the butter mixture to a boil and cook it for 30 seconds. Stir the mixture often to prevent it from scorching or forming a skin on top. Remove the saucepan from the stove and stir in the chocolate chips. Keep stirring until the chocolate chips melt. If the chocolate chips are not melting at all, place the saucepan back onto the stove, and turn the heat on to low. Stir the mixture until the chocolate chips melt, then remove the saucepan from heat. Let the mixture cool a little before pouring it over the brownies. The mixture will thicken a little as it cools. This will not only make it easier to spread, but also prevent it from soaking into the brownies. Consider sprinkling chopped walnuts over the fudge topping. This is not completely necessary, but it will give your brownies some extra flavor and texture. How much chopped walnuts you add is entirely up to you, but you still want to be able to see the fudge frosting. Allow the frosting to set before cutting and serving the brownies. The frosting will eventually harden up like fudge. Once the frosting is set and the brownies are completely coo, you can cut them into squares and serve them.
sentences: Making the Brownies Preheat your oven to 350ºF (177ºC) and grease a jelly roll or brownie pan.
You can use butter or cooking spray to grease the pan.
You can use a 9 by 13-inch (22.86 by 33.02 centimeters) pan, or a 10 by 15-inch (25.4 by 38.1 centimeters) pan.
Beat the butter and sugar until light and creamy.
You can do this using a handheld mixer, an electric stand mixer, or even a food processor.
You can also do it by hand, but it will take longer.
Keep mixing the butter and sugar until they are evenly combined.
To make the process go by faster, cut the butter into smaller cubes first.
Slowly beat the eggs in, one at a time.
If you are using an electric mixer, set the speed to low, and add the eggs in while it is beating.
Keep beating until the eggs are evenly mixed in.
Stir in the vanilla extract and chocolate syrup, then set it aside.
Pour in the vanilla extract and chocolate syrup, then stir it until everything is evenly combined.
There should be no streaks or swirls of chocolate syrup.
Combine the flour, baking powder, and salt in a separate bowl.
In a large mixing bowl, add the flour, baking powder, and salt.
Stir them briskly together using a whisk or spoon.
Add the flour mixture into the syrup mixture and stir well.
Keep stirring until everything is evenly blended together.
Make sure that there are no lumps or clumps of flour.
If there are any, use a whisk to break them up.
Consider adding 1 cup (110 grams) of chopped walnuts or chocolate chips.
This is not completely necessary, but it will add some extra flavor and texture to your brownies.
For the chocolate chips, consider dark chocolate chips or semi-sweet chocolate chips.
Pour the batter into the pan.
Use a spatula to help spread the batter evenly across the bottom of the pan.
Bake the brownies for 22 to 40 minutes, depending on the size of the pan you are using.
The brownies are ready when the center springs back if you press down on it lightly.
Another way to check for doneness is by sticking a toothpick in the center.
If it comes out clean, the brownies are ready.
If you are using a 9 by 13-inch (22.86 by 33.02 centimeters) pan, bake the brownies for 35 to 40 minutes.
If you are using a 10 by 15-inch (25.4 by 38.1 centimeters) pan, bake the brownies for 22 to 30 minutes.
Take the brownies out of the oven and let them cool, about 5 to 10 minutes.
While the brownies are cooling, you can start preparing the frosting.
Making the Frosting Heat the butter, milk, and sugar in a saucepan until the butter melts and the sugar dissolves.
Pour the milk into a medium-sized saucepan, then add the sugar.
Cut the butter into smaller cubes, and toss it in.
Cook the mixture over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the butter melts and the sugar dissolves.
Bring the butter mixture to a boil and cook it for 30 seconds.
Stir the mixture often to prevent it from scorching or forming a skin on top.
Remove the saucepan from the stove and stir in the chocolate chips.
Keep stirring until the chocolate chips melt.
If the chocolate chips are not melting at all, place the saucepan back onto the stove, and turn the heat on to low.
Stir the mixture until the chocolate chips melt, then remove the saucepan from heat.
Let the mixture cool a little before pouring it over the brownies.
The mixture will thicken a little as it cools.
This will not only make it easier to spread, but also prevent it from soaking into the brownies.
Consider sprinkling chopped walnuts over the fudge topping.
This is not completely necessary, but it will give your brownies some extra flavor and texture.
How much chopped walnuts you add is entirely up to you, but you still want to be able to see the fudge frosting.
Allow the frosting to set before cutting and serving the brownies.
The frosting will eventually harden up like fudge.
Once the frosting is set and the brownies are completely coo, you can cut them into squares and serve them.
